Line 38: Line 38:
===Formation, early years (1972â1981)===
===Formation, early years (1972â1981)===
â
[[File:Movimento Sociale Italiano 1972-95.jpg|thumb|115px|The FN was model- led on the Italian [[Italian Social Movement|MSI]].]]
 
While the ON had competed some local elections itself since 1970, it decided on its second congress in June 1972 to establish a new political party to contest the [[French legislative election, 1973|1973 legislative elections]].<ref>Shields, 2007, pp. 163â164.</ref><ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 36â37.</ref> The party was formally launched on 5 October 1972, under the name '''National Front for French Unity''' (''Front national pour l'unitÃ© franÃ§aise''), or '''National Front''' for short.<ref name=s169>Shields, 2007, p. 169.</ref> In order to create a broad movement, the ON sought to model the new party (as it earlier had sought to model itself) on the more established [[Italian Social Movement]] (MSI), and it adopted a French version of the MSI tricolour flame as its official logo.<ref>Shields, 2007, pp. 159, 169.</ref><ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 31, 36â37.</ref> It wanted to unite the various French far-right currents, and initially brought together Le Pen and his nationalist group, [[Roger Holeindre|Roger Holeindre's]] Party of French Unity, [[Georges Bidault|Georges Bidault's]] Justice and Liberty movement, former Poujadists, Algeria veterans, some [[monarchism|monarchists]] and more.<ref name=s169/><ref name=dc13>DeClair, 1999, p. 13.</ref> Le Pen was chosen as the first president of the party as he was untainted with the militant public image of the ON, and was a relatively moderate figure on the far-right.<ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 38â39.</ref><ref name=s170>Shields, 2007, p. 170.</ref>
While the ON had competed some local elections itself since 1970, it decided on its second congress in June 1972 to establish a new political party to contest the [[French legislative election, 1973|1973 legislative elections]].<ref>Shields, 2007, pp. 163â164.</ref><ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 36â37.</ref> The party was formally launched on 5 October 1972, under the name '''National Front for French Unity''' (''Front national pour l'unitÃ© franÃ§aise''), or '''National Front''' for short.<ref name=s169>Shields, 2007, p. 169.</ref> In order to create a broad movement, the ON sought to model the new party (as it earlier had sought to model itself) on the more established [[Italian Social Movement]] (MSI), and it adopted a French version of the MSI tricolour flame as its official logo.<ref>Shields, 2007, pp. 159, 169.</ref><ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 31, 36â37.</ref> It wanted to unite the various French far-right currents, and initially brought together Le Pen and his nationalist group, [[Roger Holeindre|Roger Holeindre's]] Party of French Unity, [[Georges Bidault|Georges Bidault's]] Justice and Liberty movement, former Poujadists, Algeria veterans, some [[monarchism|monarchists]] and more.<ref name=s169/><ref name=dc13>DeClair, 1999, p. 13.</ref> Le Pen was chosen as the first president of the party as he was untainted with the militant public image of the ON, and was a relatively moderate figure on the far-right.<ref>DeClair, 1999, pp. 38â39.</ref><ref name=s170>Shields, 2007, p. 170.</ref>
